text: The ground trembled violently as a rock-armored beast burst from beneath the soil. Its glowing green eyes sent the birds scattering in terror.
I rolled to the side, gravel crunching beneath my boots. The beast’s claws scraped past my shoulder, striking sparks against the stones.
My breath turned to frost. Just as I steadied myself, Alicia’s silhouette flashed through the air—her cloak cutting an arc, her sword following like silver lightning.
A sharp gleam slashed across the monster’s chest, forcing it back several steps with a guttural snarl.
I spotted a crack in its armor and shouted, “Its right side—there’s a breach in the shell!”
“I see it.” Her voice was steady, movements clean and precise. Her sword cut through the air, leaving a cold streak of light behind.
The beast froze, the green glow in its eyes fading. A moment later, it collapsed with a heavy crash, its cracked armor scattering dirt and dust.
The air filled with smoke and the scent of burnt earth. Alicia sheathed her sword and turned toward me.
“Not bad,” she said calmly, though her lips curved slightly. “Next time, stay a bit farther back.”
I nodded, palms slick with sweat—but my heart raced with a strange excitement. I had survived… and even helped.
Scorch marks still stained the ground where the beast fell. The smell of smoke lingered, and sunlight filtered through the trees, glinting off her blade—cold as ice.
“That thing wasn’t born naturally,” she murmured. “It was a ‘Residual Dream’—the trace left behind by the dead.”
“Residual Dream?” I repeated, my voice still trembling.
“Yes. In places scarred by war or death, the earth keeps the last emotions of the fallen. Over time, those emotions take shape.”
She sheathed her sword completely, her expression calm again. The wind swept through the trees, carrying away the smell of blood.
“Come on,” she said with a faint smile. “The market’s just ahead—and I’ll be needing your help to carry a few things.”
